p: H. suaveolens is widely used in the treatment of malaria. It inhibits growth of both chloroquine-sensitive and chloroquine-resistant strains of Plasmodium falciparum under in vitro conditions. The chemical constituent responsible for this activity is dehydroabietinol that causes transformation of erythrocytes from discocytes to stomatocytes. Later, a diterpenoid 13alpha-epi-dioxiabiet-8(14)-en-18-ol found from petroleum ether extract of H. suaveolens leaves also shows antiplasmodial activity [ 82, 83].
